posts.cooked: Our software team had a discussion about switching to Python due to ease of programming, but I’m curious if this is even possible? I mostly work in scouting software so this isnt my area of expertise

posts.name: Tinnittin
posts.cooked:
Yep! See:

The WPI Robotics Library (WPILib) is the standard software library provided for teams to write code for their FRC ® robots. WPILib contains a set of useful classes and subroutines for interfacing w...

Welcome! RobotPy is a project created by a community of FIRST mentors and students dedicated to developing python-related projects for the FIRST Robotics Competition. This documentation site contai...

link_counts.title: What is WPILib? — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Floyd Moore
posts.cooked:
I can (with experience) say Yes. This year we had some issues with our java swerve code and a previous mentor was able to get it going in robotpy.  Since we then had swerve code in python we continued to develop the robot in python.

https://github.com/Team997Coders/pyswerve_2024

Now it isn’t without it’s difficulties.  We have had issues with the robot spinning out of control and with numerous loop overruns.  But it does work.  It uses a number of more advanced python idioms, so be warned.

Give yourself plenty of time, and PLEASE, PLEASE follow the standard FRC code structure.  It will make your life infinitely easier.  Our code is NOT in the standard structure and is a bit hard to follow.

It would make an interesting off-season project.
have you guys had any performance issues in comparison to your java code?

posts.name: Floyd Moore
posts.cooked: As noted in another post.  We have had some issues with our gyro (NavX) and are still working on issues with loop overruns and too much information on the SmartDashboard, but basic functionality is there and there does not seem to be any issues in performance.  The loop errors could be worse due to the extra python processing, but we don’t have any hard data on this.

posts.name: Nathan Fletcher
posts.cooked: What issues? My team uses Java and NavX and don’t really have any issues

posts.name: Floyd Moore
posts.cooked: Disconnect/Reconnect and the NavX not providing any data.  And yes we have tries multiple NavX boards and also connected to it using the NavX GUI and the board seems fine.

posts.name: Patrick Ambli
posts.cooked: As others have said it is completely possible to code your robot in Python however WPILib’s support for Python is very new so I would somewhat caution against using it. We had our middle school team try out RobotPy this year and we ran into a number of problems with it. There isn’t great 3rd party library support for it yet and there just isn’t the 10+ years of documentation and resources built-up that  Java and C++ have.
The current revision of robotpy has been around since 2020 with support for ctre/rev libraries all along. Across revisions, robotpy has been around since 2010.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: That’s unfortunate to hear. Our experience was the exact opposite- we had our team try to pick it up over the summer, and they were thrilled at how much easier it was to work with than java.

posts.name: Patrick Ambli
posts.cooked: Interesting, it’s possible I just haven’t spent enough time with RobotPy yet. Our middle school team only meets once a week and when they are meeting my time is split between them and our actual high school team.  Also, the fact that the high school team is naturally more self-sufficient is probably biasing me. I’m obviously going to have to solve a lot more problems for the middle schoolers than the high schoolers.

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
We switched from Java to Python this year.  It’s been great.  I actually think the flexibility of Python is much easier for new students.  For example, we don’t have dozens of command files, subsystems etc.  We just have a drivetrain.py file, and anything we don’t do in compositions as far as commands go all get built in to the bottom of the drivetrain file.

I’m a huge fan.

The only thing so far that I have found lacking support is in the CTRE library.  They do some great things on the Simulation side in Java that are on their roadmap (they’ve said) but did not make it into the 2024 season for Python.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
NewtonCrosby:

For example, we don’t have dozens of command files, subsystems etc. We just have a drivetrain.py file, and anything we don’t do in compositions as far as commands go all get built in to the bottom of the drivetrain file.

This shouldn’t depend on language, FWIW.  The Java and C++ command libraries both support this kind of architecture.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

This shouldn’t depend on language, FWIW.  The Java and C++ command libraries both support this kind of architecture.

It absolutely does depend on language, as some are more flexible than others.

I agree with you though, there are flexible ways that a Java team could do things the way we structure things with Python.  It’s not always intuitive for teams with historical knowledge and pre-conditioned mentors/code bases.

Python is a nice bridge between the two worlds.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I’m just not seeing the difference, here.  Even in a class-based model, nothing stops you from moving single-subsystem Commands into the subsystem scope in Java - there were teams doing this in the old (pre-2020) library.

There are certainly more bad legacy examples for Java than for Python, and I guess I could see that as a reason for switching.  But that’s not a language feature.
